docs.title: BioKb Taxtree: A Python Library for Querying NCBI Taxonomy Data
docs.text: BioKb Taxtree is a Python library designed to load and query data from the NCBI Taxonomy database in a structured and efficient manner. The library enables users to store taxonomy data in a database, allowing for fast querying and advanced tree-based searches.

docs.title: Flexible Database Management with SQLAlchemy
docs.text:
A key feature of BioKb Taxtree is its database-agnostic design, made possible by its integration with SQLAlchemy, a powerful Python SQL toolkit and Object-Relational Mapper (ORM). Because of this, the library supports multiple Database Management Systems (DBMS), including:

  • PostgreSQL
  • MySQL / MariaDB
  • SQLite
  • Microsoft SQL Server
  • Oracle Database

This flexibility allows researchers and developers to choose the database system that best fits their needs, whether for local analysis (e.g., SQLite) or enterprise-scale applications (e.g., PostgreSQL or Oracle).

docs.title: Querying Name Classes in NCBI Taxonomy
docs.text:
NCBI Taxonomy assigns multiple name classes to taxa, reflecting different ways a species or group can be identified. BioKb Taxtree allows users to query taxonomy data based on these name classes, including:

  • scientific name (officially recognized name)
  • synonym (alternative names)
  • common name (vernacular names)
  • misspelling (frequent misidentifications)
  • authority (taxonomic authorship details)
  • equivalent name (alternative valid names)
  • in-part (partial names)
  • includes (grouping broader than a single taxon)
  • genbank common name (name used in GenBank records)
  • blast name (name used in BLAST searches)

docs.title: Advanced Tree-Based Searching
docs.text:
The library provides several functions for navigating the NCBI taxonomy tree, enabling users to:

✅ Search for taxa by name or taxonomic ID ✅ Retrieve parent or child nodes in the hierarchy ✅ Find sibling taxa ✅ Trace lineage from a taxon to the root ✅ List all descendant taxa of a given node

Additionally, BioKb Taxtree supports branch-specific searches, meaning users can limit queries to specific taxonomic subtrees, such as all species within a given genus, family, or higher taxonomic rank.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: BioKb Taxtree is a powerful tool for researchers, bioinformaticians, and database managers working with NCBI taxonomy data. By supporting multiple DBMS systems via SQLAlchemy and offering advanced tree-searching capabilities, the library enables efficient and flexible taxonomy management for various applications in genomics, systematics, and biodiversity research.

docs.title: Background to NCBI taxonomy tree
docs.text: The NCBI Taxonomy Tree is a comprehensive hierarchical classification of organisms, maintained by the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). It provides a structured representation of the evolutionary relationships among species, covering a vast range of life forms, from bacteria and viruses to plants and animals. The taxonomy tree integrates data from multiple biological databases, including genome sequencing projects, protein and nucleotide sequence repositories, and scientific literature.

docs.title: Purpose and Utility
docs.text:
The NCBI taxonomy serves as a standard reference for researchers in various biological fields, including genetics, genomics, phylogenetics, and bioinformatics. Some key uses include:

  1. Organizing Biological Data

  2. It helps categorize genetic sequences and other biological information in a way that reflects evolutionary relationships.

  3. Phylogenetic and Evolutionary Studies

  4. Researchers use it to study how species are related through common ancestry, aiding in the understanding of evolutionary history.

  5. Genome Annotation

  6. When sequencing new genomes, scientists use taxonomy data to classify and annotate genes based on known species.

  7. Database Searching and Filtering

  8. Bioinformatics tools use NCBI taxonomy to filter results when searching genetic databases like GenBank, making it easier to find sequences from specific organisms.

  9. Metagenomics and Environmental Studies

  10. In microbial ecology, NCBI taxonomy helps classify unknown organisms found in environmental samples through DNA sequencing.

  11. Biomedical and Pharmaceutical Research

  12. It plays a role in studying pathogens, developing vaccines, and tracking disease-causing organisms by providing a reference framework.

The NCBI Taxonomy database is continuously updated and curated, ensuring accuracy and consistency across biological research disciplines. It is widely used in conjunction with tools like BLAST (Basic Local Alignment Search Tool) for sequence comparison and classification.

docs.title: The Importance of NCBI Taxonomy for Ethnobotany and Ethnopharmacology
docs.text:
The NCBI Taxonomy plays a crucial role in ethnobotany (the study of traditional plant use by humans) and ethnopharmacology (the study of medicinal plants and their applications). These fields rely on precise plant identification and classification to ensure accurate documentation of traditional knowledge, phytochemical studies, and drug discovery.

NCBI Taxonomy is particularly useful because it integrates molecular data, linking plant species with genetic sequences available in databases like GenBank. This is essential for:

  1. Molecular Identification and Authentication

  2. Ensuring that medicinal plants are correctly identified at the genetic level to avoid misidentifications, which can have serious consequences in pharmacology.

  3. Phylogenetic Studies

  4. Understanding the evolutionary relationships between medicinal plants and their relatives, which can help in discovering new bioactive compounds.

  5. Genetic Resources for Drug Development

  6. Connecting plant taxonomy with genomic and metabolic data to explore plant-derived medicinal compounds.

  7. Tracking Plant-Derived Pathogens and Contaminants

  8. Identifying contaminants or pathogens in herbal medicines using molecular data.

docs.title: Comparison with IPNI and WCVP
docs.text:
The International Plant Names Index (IPNI) and The World Checklist of Vascular Plants (WCVP) are both taxonomic databases that focus on plant nomenclature and classification but differ significantly from NCBI Taxonomy.

Feature NCBI Taxonomy IPNI WCVP Main Focus Genetic and molecular taxonomy, linked to biological databases Nomenclature and publication details of plant names Comprehensive checklist of vascular plants with distribution and synonymy Data Type Genetic sequences, phylogenetics, taxonomy Scientific plant names and authorship Taxonomic classification, synonymy, and distribution Primary Use Molecular biology, genomics, pharmacology, biodiversity research Plant name standardization and botanical taxonomy Plant conservation, ecology, biodiversity studies Integration with Other Databases Linked to GenBank, BLAST, and molecular tools Used by botanical taxonomists for name verification Integrated with Kew's plant data and conservation databases Updates and Curation Constantly updated with molecular data and species sequences Focuses on historical and current plant names, less frequent updates Regularly updated, but primarily focused on taxonomy and distribution Relevance to Ethnobotany/Ethnopharmacology High (links genetic data with taxonomy, useful for medicinal plant studies) Medium (useful for verifying plant names but lacks molecular data) Medium (helps in identifying plant distribution but lacks molecular data)

docs.title: Advantages of NCBI Taxonomy
docs.text: ✅ Molecular Data Integration – Provides genetic sequences for precise plant identification, crucial for pharmacological research. ✅ Evolutionary Relationships – Helps understand phylogenetics and the chemical potential of related species. ✅ Searchable in Genomic Tools – Can be used in BLAST and other bioinformatics tools for genetic research.

docs.title: Disadvantages of NCBI Taxonomy
docs.text: ❌ Not Primarily Focused on Botanical Nomenclature – Lacks comprehensive coverage of plant names, synonyms, and taxonomic history. ❌ Limited Ecological and Distribution Data – Unlike WCVP, it does not provide geographical distribution or conservation status. ❌ Dependent on Genetic Submissions – Some plant species may lack molecular data, making it less complete than classical taxonomic databases.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: For ethnobotany and ethnopharmacology, NCBI Taxonomy is superior when molecular identification is required, as it links plant species to genetic sequences. However, IPNI is better for verifying plant names, and WCVP is more useful for understanding plant distribution and conservation. The ideal approach is to use all three databases in combination to ensure accurate plant identification, nomenclature validation, and ecological understanding.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
It's highly recommended to install a virtual environment with

python3 -m venv .venv

After setup activate the environment with

source .venv/bin/activate
